head.title: Builder Rebuffs Suffolk On Low-Cost Housing

hedline.hl1: Builder Rebuffs Suffolk On Low-Cost Housing

abstract.p: SBJ Associates reportedly rejects Suffolk County legislature's grant of $1.8 million to add affordable family housing to development for older residents on former Long Island Developmental Center in Huntington (S)

block.p: The Suffolk Legislature voted last week to give the developers $1.8 million if they agreed to add affordable family housing to a much-debated plan for the former Long Island Developmental Center in Huntington.
But the developers, SBJ Associates of Garden City, will refuse the money, according to their lawyer, John A. Harras, and want to go forward with a development designed largely for older residents.

The Suffolk Legislature voted last week to give the developers $1.8 million if they agreed to add affordable family housing to a much-debated plan for the former Long Island Developmental Center in Huntington.
But the developers, SBJ Associates of Garden City, will refuse the money, according to their lawyer, John A. Harras, and want to go forward with a development designed largely for older residents.

SBJ paid the state $16.1 million for the 380-acre parcel in October. They are asking Huntington for a zoning change to allow an 18-hole golf course and 1,375 condominium and detached and semi-detached units primarily for people 55 and older.

The Suffolk legislation would award the $1.8 million if SBJ built 30 percent of the units to sell to families for $50,000 to $130,000. The developers could use the money for roads, curb cuts or other costs.

The presiding officer of the legislature, Paul J. Tonna, a Republican from Huntington and a sponsor, said the bill was ''a carrot without a stick'' to ensure that the development benefited working families and young people who have been priced out of the housing market.
''There's nothing wrong with housing for seniors,'' he said, ''but we really have to do something here for affordable housing for everyone.''

Mr. Harras said the proposed alteration could disqualify the project as a ''senior community'' under the Federal Fair Housing Act, wiping out subsidies that would hold down the cost of units for older residents.
Under the developers' plan, prices would range from $125,000 for some subsidized condominium units to $500,000 and up for detached houses. The project includes some rental units.
